Yann Martel's Life of Pi, a Man Booker Prize winner is no doubt an enchanting read..I would never have imagined it coming to life on screen, but Director Ang Lee achieves the unachievable. If you thought Crouching tiger..was exceptional, Life of Pi is even more so...the story of sixteen year old Pi who survives a shipwreck and his unending adventure in the Pacific Ocean on a lifeboat  with a Royal Bengal tiger for companyfor 227 days before he reaches the shores of Mexico. No.the tiger is not a speaking one like the benevolent lion Aslan in Chronicles of Narniait is wild and ferocious  also a survivor in the shipwreck ..while being transported from India to the Americasso then what happenssee it in the Life of Pi  an immensely watchableactually a must watch film in recent timesof an exceptional quality as was Avatar. What's so great about thisanother fantasy?....yes and no.Life of Pi is a story intended to make you believe in God and his marvelous plan.with layers and layers of revelationsthe script is unbeatable and together with Ang lee's vivid imagery , cinematography and sensitivity .a spiritual and visual masterpiece. Cynics would like to dismiss it as a naive quest for spiritual fulfillment, but understanding Life of Pi necessitates a certain kind of awareness and sensitivity. The movie opens to the tunes of a soulful lullaby sung in Tamil while the camera in slow motion scans the zoo ... owned by Pi's family  the start of a vivid narration of Pi's childhood captured so lovingly bringing a magical quality to the mundane. The unpretentiousness of the cast and characters is heartening. Ang Lee's brief but unprejudiced and accurate portrayal of a foreign cultureis laudable The amazing part of the movie though begins after the shipwreckhow Pi survives the journey, while taking care of the needs of a full grown royal Bengal tiger while needing to save himselfthe revelations that he has, his resourcefulness , courage and spirit Ang Lee's direction and Suraj Sharma's ( young Pi's) earnestness bring conviction to Yann Martel's absurdly magical story as perfectly plausible.the unbelievably real looking tiger ( named Richard Parker! ) is actually digital the oceanic scenes are unadulterated pleasure to behold. The script is designed to make you take stock of your own life, while Pi stumbles on major revelations when Pi decides not to be scared of Richard Parker, but to learn to communicate with him as he decides to train him while battling and surviving in the stormy Pacific. Particularly poignant when he utters the words.. " Oh God I give myself to you. I am your vesselWhatever comes I want to knowshow me" Ultimately beyond our skepticism and smartness, we need to have faith and let gowith that comes a new found courage and confidence that ferries us beyond the shores of uncertainty and the unknown. Irfan Khan as the adult Pi and Tabu as the mother of young Pi are effortless actors, the young Pi played by Ayush Tandon is marked by heart tugging earnestness, and Suraj Sharma the lead Pi, chosen for his personality and "soulful eyes" ( Ang Lee in his interview) , does mesmerize you with his performance. So even without any fancy hallowed Hollywood actors, Ang Lee churns out an unexpected treat... the sort that churns you deep within. The last lament of Pi is that Richard Parker , the tiger leaves him at the shores of Mexico without a proper goodbye( maybe too much to expect of a tiger) but it is to remind us of the importance of proper goodbyes in our lives and maybe not to expect when we do not receive them.

''I had to tame him,'' (Pi) realizes. ''It was not a question of him or me, but of him and me. We were, literally and figuratively, in the same boat." From Life of Pi by Yann Martel.You will see no more imaginative film this year than Life of Pi, whose conceit of a young Indian boy stranded with a Bengal Tiger in a lifeboat amid the Pacific Ocean is fantastical yet real in its metaphoric implications. While the framing device of a story told to a stranger uses the old flashback, the lonely lifeboat is as new as any story told in the last century.The film begs interpretation from the multiplicity of religions to the place of mankind in a hostile, Darwinian world. Ultimately the benign brotherhood of beasts and humans is affirmed not so much by lofty philosophy but by the necessity of man and beast working together to survive.The digital rendering of animals, especially the Bengal Tiger, is beautiful to behold. The opening scene in Pi's family zoo could be right out of Terence Malick's visionary camera, a montage of nature gorgeous in its simplicity. The several formalistic shots of the boat at night are worthy of the best lighting in the best aquariums in the world. Together with the impressive use of 3D, director Ang Lee has visually taken us from the opulence of Crouching Tiger and the minimalism of Brokeback Mountain into a fusion world of fancy and reality. The images are stunning.In the end, Lee is interested in the individual's place in the universe as he struggles to harness nature and yet live in harmony with these elements. The conflict with the gross cook aboard the Japanese cargo ship taking Pi's family and animals to Canada is emblematic of the challenges facing the gifted with the groundings. Pi's relationship with tiger "Richard Parker" represents all mankind's struggle to live in harmony with the forces it cannot control."Believing in everything is the same as believing in nothing," says Pi's father because Pi samples religions from Hinduism and Buddhism to Catholicism and Judaism and wants them all. Although it is not given to us to have them all, Pi's piety practically makes us believers in the universal brotherhood.The Life of Pi is everyone's life; the film is one of the best of the year and, even remembering the greatness of The Old Man and the Sea, Moby Dick, and Billy Budd, the best you will ever see about a boy, a tiger, and a boat.

Excellent. Beautiful Ocean Scenes. Somehow the story works, even though it is a bit of a 'stretch' at times for one's credulity. Like having a hyena, an orangutan, and a (seasick) tiger all aboard the same large raft as Pi (the main character) after their ship sinks in a storm. Wonderful cinematography. Survival is the name of the game here, and the need to be resourceful and adaptive.One criticism is that I would have liked to see more exposition of the ending, as it was indicated in the novel.***Spoiler Alert*** Pi survives !

Visually stunning I will admit. Irrfan Khan is fantastic in his part. These are the only highlights as the story is in my opinion overrated and very boring. I could not help that the film's overall message was that if you are not a person of faith in a higher being then you are bad person . I dislike people with attitudes like this. Whether or not you have faith in a particular religion or a higher power a person should not be judged by this characteristic which is what this film does. This is how I have interpreted this film and for all I know that may not be the overall message of the film but that is the way that it comes across to me. With that aside I could not help but find many similarities with Tim Burton's magnificent film Big Fish. This film (and I am assuming the novel that it is based on) feels like one big rip off of Big Fish. I like Ang Lee's films but this is by far his worst and in my opinion stole the Oscar nomination for best director from Ben Affleck (who definitely should have won). Do yourself a favour and watch Big Fish, it's a much better film.

I loved this until he had to tell the second"fake" story to the Japanese company. I really don't see it a good addition to the film. I may have considered this film as one of my favorite except for the ladt quarter of hour. Anyway I had a lot of fun watching it but still I'm not convinced that his story can lead to Creator(God) because it's not objective and is close to the prophets stories and tales!
Beautifully shot! Though the philosophic essence is not enough.

reviews.review_title: An amazing movie with an incledable story.
reviews.content: The way they told the story is pretty much incledable. You get to see a story that's both real and fake but they meet in the middle, so everything is even. Watching the movie will bring you happiness and sadness at the same time. At first you might think that being on a boat with a tiger is a bit too much but in reality that's the perfect fit to tell an incledable story and make the movie unique on it's own standings. The only part that I did not like was the one when they didn't show what happened to the Tiger after he went in the jungle. But other than that the acting and the way they say and bring the story was amazing!

reviews.review_title: I like more about the second story
reviews.content: Life of pi is such a beautiful movie that the magnificent scenery haunted my mind long after I had watched it. In addition to the scenery, the storyline is also thought provoking. Born in a non-religious family, I have got no tendency to believe in god. As a student who is particularly interest in science and chose physics as my major at college, it is especially hard for me to believe the existence of any form of god. But this movie really set me thinking. Actually I do not intend to believe the second story, which is generally claimed to be the true story of Pi. Instead, I think the first story which suggested the existence of a real tiger is more romantic and thought-provoking. In my opinion, the second story stress more about the fight between a ferocious Pi and a thoughtful Pi while the second story pay more attention to Pi's adventurous journey and amazing coincidence which proclaims the existence of god. In the mind of a science student, events in life are no more than accidental incidents, which happened predetermined by probability. However, like the story of pulp fiction, the occurrence of certain series of events that led to a romantic or miraculous ending just prompt us to believe in god. I have not seen the miraculous ending yet, but nonetheless I did experience some coherent events that happened one by one which seem to guide me to some secret places although it has not been apparent yet. After watching this movie, I feel better about my past and become more optimistic about the future. Maybe someday in the future, I will believe in something, like god.

Very Impressive. I think it is the best Symbolic movie I ever seen. The Story writer is just awesome and the Director is also because he makes the story more beautiful. "All that the Island gave him by day , it took away at night", "When you look into his eye, you are seeing your own emotion reflect back at you' There are so many quotation like this in the movie impressed very much. This movie is not like other symbolic movie, It represents a story with some of other story. There are many of the people have story like this and they can not express because there is no evidence of the story. People always prefer a story which is very easy but sometimes there are some exception occurs which is very hard to trust.

Life of Pi might not be one of my favorite movies this year, but it is one i would recommend to anyone. I wish i saw it in 3d, but its also looks great in 2d. The movie is about Pi who spends a long time on a boat with a tiger. Its a great premise, but it does take a long time before that happens. We spend a long time learning about Pi's live, which was fun to watch, but still I wanted to get to the part with the tiger. The second half of the film is were it really starts. Pi's adventure with Richard parker is funny, scary, intense, sad and has some of the best visuals i have seen in any movie. However it is not the perfect film. The actor for young Pi is not really that good and the CGI is not always convincing. Still it's one of the best movies I saw this year and I can't wait to see what Ang lee will film next.

reviews.review_title: It tells you why we need religion
reviews.content: Saw the movie twice simply to make sure I don't miss every details Ang Lee wants to convey. After watching the movie the first time, I quickly went on the internet to see how others react. Luckily, some wise and experienced people are able to interpret Ang Lee's plots better.Art is something that everyone has his own interpretation. Like mirrors reflecting your individual thinking. This movie is an excellent mirror one can have a peek of himself. Religious and cheerful people saw the will of god, atheists saw the absurdity of religions, and the downright pessimistic realists saw a cruel dark phase of life. Under the surface of a seemingly logical story of animal lies a cruel true story we cannot bear to stare. Life can be cruel and harsh. Reality can be hurting and heartbreaking. This is why and when we need religion. With "suspension of disbelief", the insurance guys, the novelist, and we audience, can all believe in the exterior animal story and have a peace of mind.

The life of Pi is a visually amazing, smart funny awe-inspiring film- definitely worth a watch!The cinematography and CGI coupled with the irresistible story of a young boy with an open-mind, carefree and loving heart; set with the vast ocean as a canvas makes for an epic tale of survival and courage. This film not only captivates the audience with its majestic imagery, it holds a solid story which moves the viewers through the museum of Pi's most intimate experiences effortlessly. This really is a tale of Man Vs. Beast, Man Vs. Man and Man Vs. The elements. A tale of passion and belief in something greater than yourself, in surrendering yourself to fate and living to see another day.

Very rarely does a movie come along, and capture my attention from beginning to end. I've been curious to see what all the hoopla was about this film, but never got around to watching it. It came on T.V. yesterday, so I decided to give it a try.Life of Pi exceeded my expectations. The characterization of Pi was astounding, as was the acting and directing.The cinematography and special effects blew me away. I did not know until I began investigating that the Bengal tiger was not real! It certainly seemed real enough to me!Suraj Sharma did an outstanding job portraying Pi. I was sucked right in to every dramatic moment, and even the moments of lull. The relationship between Pi and the tiger was interesting, not your typical Disneyesque type flick where everyone lives happily ever after. I wouldn't exactly say they became "friends", which may be what I found so intriguing. How Pi figure out how to survive and coexist with the tiger was also interesting to watch as it unfolded. I would not recommend this movie for younger children. Some scenes were a little overpowering, and too intense for young eyes. The ending of the movie threw me for a loop, and has been keeping me thinking about it even into the next day. I'm still not exactly sure what happened, what was the truth or what was made up by Pi. My husband has always loved the sea, and stories like Kon-Tiki. I've told him he has to watch this movie, and I definitely want to watch it again.

reviews.review_title: What kind of story do you prefer?
reviews.content: I think this movie is a master piece in storytelling. The opening is so calm and colorful and both idea of the film is shown: First, the animals are somehow like us; second, we the humans are somehow like them. Then the story goes and goes till the original story and the see trip. We have been told two stories. Two good stories, and both are unprovable. Then we should choose what story is better, and we see that this is an irony, because we find out that in the real life, we should choose between two stories too, and that is simply fascinating.Also the role of the principle animal, tiger, is very important. In one story he (honestly I didn't know the tiger was either "he" or "she" but I say "he" because they called him Richard Parker) is the main reason to keep awake the conciseness of pi and therefor to keep alive him. In the other story, he is the pi himself, and what we see in first story is indeed the symbols of pi's actions. So the idea of animals are people and people are animals also narrated very well and cleverly in this movie. I want say another two things. One is that the idea of interchanging used in everywhere of Life of Pi, like "a Canadian who's come to French India in search of a story" and "l know an Indian in French Canada with the most incredible story to tell." And the other thing is I saw "All Is Lost" before this movie and this two movies are so different with each other.

As this review is marked to contain spoilers, the reader is probably already familiar with the colorful and visually appealing scenes in the film, so I won't comment about it. All the 4 stars of this review are because of the visuals.Much more important is the moral message it conveys: one of the two stories told is of a fairy-tale kind. It contains impossible events, and, as stated in the film ending, is simply not true. The second is a drastic, but true story. Both have the same beginning and the same outcome in the end to Pi but differ terribly in between. The message one gets from the film is that telling lies is a good thing. Myself being a scientist always seeking the truth I cannot disagree more.Moreover, throughout it contains multiple references to God(s). Very rough ones and obviously untrue.Overall the film conveys Middle Ages morality: tell a beautiful lie, attribute events to God(s), and don't mention the true causes. Think twice if you plan to show this film to a kid.

here are a lot of positive and admirable things about Ang Lee's latest Life of Pi. Cinematographer Claudio Miranda captures the most uproarious and glorious shots captured this year thus far. The 3D effects are some of the best ever seen and feels absolutely necessary in a film so heavy handed with religious tones. What Mychael Danna achieves in Lee's film has just placed him in the forefront of great film composers working today. He continues to impress with his musical range, envelopes the film's message and thematic narrative in somber and beautiful melodic notes. On Visual Effects alone, Life of Pi will likely land a nomination for Best Picture. What Lee invents with the ocean and the integration of the tiger and the other animals is spectacular. He allows the mood of the film and the imagery to marry each other in a ceremonial experience that stands next to Sci-Fi epics like Avatar (2009) and Hugo (2011).LEE DIREcts the film with a firm hand. He knows what he wants to say and for the most part gets his message across. Unfortunately an unfocused and at times jumbled screenplay by the great David Magee creates an atmosphere that relies more on the visuals then the narrative. Also, I'm unfamiliar with the book by Yann Martel, never read it before, so I have nothing to compare it to but much of the story's elements of surprise feel rather cheap and ill-fitting. Not sure how it will play with others but the film remains pretty consistent on the entertainment sector. Lee explains his preparation for the film at the New York Film Festival with such passion and delight. He speaks about getting Sharma properly prepared by placing him on a boat in the middle of the ocean and meeting a real life shipwreck survivor; Lee's love for the project comes through, all four years in the making. It's a directorial achievement that the Director's branch of the Academy could easily get behind. The film lands solidly on the front door of awards season with ease and could rally a loyal legion of followers. Look out for the National Board of Review to kick it offI can almost put money on it.

Finally went to theatre in order to view on the big screen but was very disappointed. The CGI effects were just OK in my book; the story certainly did not move me emotionally; and while pretty to watch it held no great moments that were believable. Whale sharks are spectacular but this one just didn't fit; it was just one more "effect" thrown in to an effect filled movie. The best director award was a joke. Steven Spielberg, Kathryn Bigelow or Ben Affleck were far more deserving. Don't bother paying for tickets just watch at home for free. The "Academy" seems to have something against Spielberg and I think that snubbing Affleck for even getting nominated, in spite of winning all other director awards, shows a lack of respect for his work. All in all "Life of Pi" was just boring and and exercise in fancy CGI effects. The continuity of PI's hair length did not jive with time spent in a boat. At one point the boat is completely full of water and next scene the water is gone. When a viewer starts to notice little things like that the director has a problem.
Haters gonna hate. But this was something only Ang Lee could do. The creativity and ingenuity involved in this movie was something Hollywood really needs more. This movie was a work of art.

reviews.review_title: A Christian Perspective of Life of Pi
reviews.content: It is not uncommon for a Hollywood produced movie to question spirituality, the existence of God, and supremacy of religion, but rarely are these doubts projected in such a powerful way as they are in Ang Lee's Life of Pi. The Oscar winning film is based on Yann Martel's 2001 novel of the same name. The movie centers around a 17-year old Indian boy named Piscine Molitor "Pi" Patel, the son of a zoo keeper, who survives a shipwreck aboard a lifeboat with a Bengal Tiger named Richard Parker.Prior to the shipwreck, Pi, who was raised Hindu by his mother, had experimented with both Christianity and Islam. Pi discovers Christianity and Islam and incorporates the philosophies of these faiths into his Hindu lifestyle, culture, and spiritual pursuit. For example, in his prayers, Pi thanks Krishna for the salvation and sacrifice of Jesus Christ. Pi's father, who has thoroughly rejected any religion, thinks that Pi is ridiculous and actually says something that seems to make the most sense of anything in the movie. Pi's father tells him, "Believing in everything at the same time is the same as believing in nothing at all." However, throughout the film, Pi's father is cast in a negative light. Pi's father decides to move his family, and his animals, by ship from India to Canada to start a new life. But a savage storm ensues and the ship sinks, killing all its passengers, save for a few animals and Pi.After the shipwreck, Pi shares a lifeboat with a zebra, who suffered a broken leg, a female orangutan, who lost all her children in the wreck, and a cackling hyena. Before long, the hyena gets scared and hungry and begins to attack the defenseless zebra. The hyena kills the zebra and then begins to attack and kill the orangutan. While the hyena is in the process of killing the orangutan, Richard Parker jumps out from underneath a tarp and kills the hyena, while also trying to kill Pi as well. Pi then builds an inflatable life raft and attaches it by rope to the side of the lifeboat in order to distance himself from the tiger. But he knows that tigers are very good swimmers, so he catches fish in order to keep Richard Parker fed and to prevent the tiger from eating him.Amazingly, Pi and Richard Parker are able to both stay alive as their lifeboat washes up to shore in Mexico. While recovering in a hospital bed, Pi must tell his story to two of the ship's insurance adjusters who have come to question him about the incident in which no one survived but himself. Pi tells them his fantastic tale of how he survived 227 days in the Pacific Ocean with a hungry Bengal tiger. The insurance adjusters don't believe Pi. They ask him to give them "the truth". Pi then gives them a similar story, but changes the animal characters to humans, casting the tiger as himself. The insurance company chooses the more fantastic story with the animals, to which Pi responds, "And so it goes with God".This movie is the embodiment of post-modern philosophy and thought. The prevailing sentiment of post-modernity is that there is no ultimate truth. Everyone must choose their own truth and must not infringe their truth on others. All religions lead to the same truth. Pi seems to emphasize that we are to choose the story that we like the best and believe that one, although it will ultimately lead you on the same path as the other stories and religions. Everyone's spiritual path leads to the same outcome. Everyone worships the same God.This same type of thought is expressed by Pilate in John 18:38. Christ had just said, "For this purpose I was born and for this purpose I have come into the world--to bear witness to the truth. Everyone who is of the truth listens to my voice." Pilate then condescendingly retorts, "What is truth?" Pilate responds in a very post-modern relativistic manner. Pilate proves that he is not a believer because Christ had just said that those who hear His voice will recognize the truth. Such is the case today. Only the elect of Christ will be able distinguish truth from falsity. The reality is that there is only one truth. Christ says in John 14:6, "I am the way, and the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me." There is no other way to experience truth and salvation except through Jesus Christ. All other religions offer false hope.Life of Pi, while visually stunning and entertaining, is an allegory of a young man trying to find spiritual truth in this world. Truth is very real and literal. It is not an allegory or a metaphor, but is presented in very clear and precise statements in the Word of God.

reviews.review_title: Visuals are this film's shining achievement
reviews.content: Anytime you come into a movie having already read the book it is based on you will have biases. It's rather unavoidable. I did read the book beforehand, and I did the best to avoid pointing out all of the differences in my head, because to do that is to just ruin the movie for myself, when I should just give it a chance. Now, anytime a book has fantastic places or scenes, there is eager anticipation to see it realized visually. This movie delivers on that front and creates scenes rather similar to how I thought they would be and other times make them even greater. What is really missing from the movie is some of the details and stories early on about the zoo animals which was really my favorite part of the book, but it is very understandable that these are missing in favor of the larger events of the main story. I believe ultimately any short coming in the movie was also a short coming of the book's narrative: the way it drags a little in the middle and the surprising ambiguity in the ending leave something to be desired. The book is better, but you can get by with just checking out the film.

First of all, I have to admit that this is a great movie to be seen for it's exquisite picture, realistic animation, great composition. But I rate it as mediocre because I was disappointed of it's content. Basically it's about a child who's searching for God so eagerly, that as an adult he identifies himself as a Hindu Muslim Christian who is occasionally teaching Kaballah...I did not read the book, but in the movie this religious mix is accentuated but so superficially treated that it was annoying for me not understanding that child's religious philosophy, despite the director's hint contained in the father's warning that having several religions means actually having none... The story of Jesus was also misfitted... Pi Patel, during the quest of his life, finds himself as human, as son of God, as a tiger, for us to later realize that all the story he describes was actually a mastermind allegory of the real situation, with the explanation that we like to believe the beautiful stories, not necessarily the real ones...Pitiful, pathetic and sad religious thinking
Do yourself a favour and avoid this movie . waste of time after all .

I thought that life of Pi was a very beautifully written script, and the characters did a magnificent job in acting and cinematography. This isn't your average movie. This movie isn't something I normally would go Watch. That is why I just needed to share my experience with all of you, so you also can go and Watch this great movie and experience something new. As the movie progressed I got more and more excited about how Pi develops on his amazing journey for the most precious thing that he owns - his life, even though he struggles to do so. The boy learned a lot from the tiger as well as the vicious animal from the boy. I also thought it was really sad when Pi lost his entire family in the shipwreck and the only thing that kept him going on strong was his true faith in God and the friendship of the Tiger Paco. I love this movie, because it teaches me so much about the cultures and daily lives of Asian Indians. Please do see this movie.

I wanted to write a review of this film soon after I watched it in theaters as I doubted if I would remember it in the future. Walking into the theater the poster outside read "THE NEXT AVATAR, LIFE OF PI". Not being a fan of Avatar I wasn't sure why the makers of this film would want to compare their work to it. The movie began with a long, dragging opening sequence containing various animals and sights in India and it really set the pace for the rest of the movie. The acting was excellent but I really never "beleived" the movie. From the cheesy flashback sequences, awkward moments between the writer and the main characters older self and the entire middle of the movie stranded at sea sequence which seemed to last hours on end. A mash up of Titanic, Cast Away, The Jungle Book and Avatar made me think more of those movies that the actual one I was watching. Fantastic special effects unfortunately turned a movie that I found believable in the beginning to one that I felt was straight out of a children's picture book by the end.

reviews.review_title: A spectacular visualization of a marvelous book.
reviews.content: If you were enraptured by the book, this film magnificently presents the text into a film. it is a great example of a film BASED on a book. the film does not and cannot stand on its own. the book explored great ideas of existence / religion, goes deep into loneliness, fear, love, family, survival, death, companionship or life in general. that is the key element as to why the movie can not stand on it's own. because the lessons from the book will only be learned through the book.what's so great about the film is that, it may not teach all those ideals in depth, but it makes you realize them with the character. the movie is an experience. it is a marvelous journey with Pi. as far as the technicalities of the film, acting, directing, editing, cinematography, effects, score, screenplay... nothing short of BRILLIANT. it was probably best described by the Oscar recipients themselves, as a feat that was seemingly impossible but at the end of the day, well done. because Pi's undertaking may have not been an effective and awe- inspiring delivery by just a mediocre actor. the majesty and the perils of the pacific was excellently presented. the unfolding of the story was sound.1 notch down a 10 of 10, because the film would only make complete and utter sense and value with the book.

Life of PI (2012)Major Cast and Crew (on credit basis)Director By: Ang Lee Written By: David Magee (Screenplay)Yann Martel (Novel)Lead Cast Pi Patel - Suraj Sharma (Protagonist) Adult Pi Patel - Irrfan KhanParallel Lead11-12 years Pi Patel - Ayush Tondon 5 years Pi Patel - Gautam Belur Santosh Patel - Adil Hussain (Pi's Father) Gita Patel - Tabu (Pi's mother) Ravi Patel - Vibish Sivakumar (Pi's elder brother,18-19 years) Ravi (13-14 years) - Mohd Abbas Khaleeli Ravi (7 years) - Ayan Khan Writer - Rafe SpallSupporting cast Anandi (Pi's beloved) - Sharvanthi Sainath Cook - Gerard Depardieu Insurance Investigators - James Saito, Jun Naito Mama Ji - Elie Alouf and othersSynopsis: An Indian man, relocated from Pondicherry to Canada, named Pi Patel narrates the story of his catastrophic voyage and sinking of a Cargo ship carrying his family and zoo animals to an author. In the Pacific Ocean on a life boat coterie by a Bengal tiger, named by a clerical blunder -Richard Parker, his only hope and companion who made 'the vegetarian Pi' catch fish to feed him and survive for a long, extricate and saved himself to be eaten by the tiger and abrogated by the sea.Himmilicious Review: Heard since childhood "Where there's a will, there's a way" and "A straw supports a drowning man" Stendhal said "A very small degree of hope is sufficient to cause the birth of love" and the movie is all about Hope, Human expectation, Belief in 'Gods' or 'religions', fight for life,not quitting and positive approach.Yes, Winners never quit and quitter never wins!If it's movie, it's Hollywood and now this time in fraternization with Bollywood's impeccable actors Irrfan Khan, Tabu and a preeminent debut of nineteen years Delhi boy Suraj Sharma. and of course 'Mr.Richard Parker" Life of Pi is an adaptation of the book 'Life of Pi" by Yann Martel. The story was apparently unfilmable 'non-fictioned' fiction but Ang lee (the incredible 'hulk' director) did it. A teen abiding more than two hundred days on a life boat, being the only human survivor with a Bengal tiger who wants to eat him! I didn't read the book and came to know about it after the movie only. WOW! What an adventurous journey of a man left me speechless giving Goosebumps. It's another remarkable achievement in the account of the director, both creative and monetary. The film starts with narrative chit chat of Pi (known and bantered for long as Piscine Molitor Patel, named after a swimming pool in France by his broad chest- thin legs uncle) with the writer and goes into flashback and tells his experience. The young Pi develops inclination for multiple religions. He does not choose one over the other because the one who believes in one religion discards the other.(Maybe he wanted to be logical and rational and his parents helped him a lot in this) He made a witty sarcasm, he was a Muslim, a Christian, a Baptist too and of course a Hindu because they have approximately 330 million 'Gods' . He falls in love in the music class, his mother asked to join and eventually leaves without "satisfactory goodbye to Anandi- the almost love of his life" His father owns a zoo in Pondicherry and decided to relocate in Canada. They had all their animals, quite a large number of beasts. The ship sunk and somehow he managed to survive on a life boat with a zebra. Later he got to know that about the hidden Hyena and the Orangutan. The Hyena kills the zebra and the Orangutan. Finally with a 'solid entry in Bollywood style' the tiger appears and kills the Hyena who wants to kill Pi. (I think the tiger meant as a parable for how clashing cultures can learn to dwell without leaving their basic beliefs ) Then the journey of survival begins, to win over another species, to deal with unfavourable conditions, correct- incorrect decisions, the carnivorous jungle, ray of hope and not quitting. The thrilling focus is on visuals, Inspiring story and the movie bumbler part of insurance investigators."When you say truth, no one believes but when you lie, all believe" He makes another story to them because they're unsatisfied with Pi's tale. They beg for some "sensible-easy to believe" story, they accept and leave.. (He replaces the animals with human characters)"so it goes with the god" ( psst psst remember OH MY GOD – Religion is to believe what makes you feel logical)I liked the movie.. You have your own interpretation. Go and watch it! You're going to love it!!Irrfan with best of his enunciating expressions ornaments the movie.My rating ***1/2

This movie is truly a stunning work of art and the novel that inspired it goes into depths that many of us rarely explore. It draws emotions throughout and the beautiful cinematography and special effects make fantasy come to life. The story bursts with hidden meanings and metaphors designed to evoke memories and feelings from your subconscious that you may have buried long ago, and parts of it - symbolically - will almost certainly overlap distinct times in anyone's lives.However I was left feeling unsatisfied.. I found the author and creator, the man who gave birth to all this wonder a lonely man - and I feel it deeply throughout his story. From a psychological perspective, perhaps a man who wants unconditional love but can't give it, someone who would choose the blue pill instead of digging deeper and finding answers to the complex questions he asks himself. He desperately seeks to find the soul and the divinity in the world - yet when a roadblock shows itself he gives up and feels he has to choose between rationality & spirituality, reality & divinity. Therein lies his struggle. Once we are able to step away and see the big picture, understand that cause has effect - and that there is no evil in that - we will find release. The adult Pi suggests that God is a choice of self delusion to make the harsh realities of life easier to digest. Consider the possibility that our search for harmony in all its reality, through actions, holy books, and everything else that exists out there is part of what we call "God" - and we form an active part of it. The concept of the divine is not out there to satisfy a need we have, it is there to inspire us to be it and to make the world more like it. If the tiger is seen as having the main purpose of keeping us alive and not a creature we truly love and wish to give comfort to, it is not going to look back and give a thanking roar before it walks away, and it will not give us peace. This is a metaphor of my own.I find it ironic that one of the main pillars of the movie is faith and hope, yet they seem to be portrayed as simply a means for survival and self delusion, and true faith is exactly what is renounced in the final metaphor and ending phrase. I'm sure the author was able to use this beautiful and complex story as a way of expressing his internal struggle - but I'm afraid he was not able to find piece by the end of it. I'd love to read something from him later in his life, where Pi allows himself to cry, to mourn, to be honest - and still find divinity in all the world's mess and reality, and in a tiger's hunger..

It didn't start too exciting, just a writer looking for a new story having been told that this older Pi had one to tell. So it starts as reminiscing of his childhood, learning of different religions and generally experiencing life etc... at this point I was thinking she'd pulled a fast one telling me I'd love the film, it looks great...But it did get better. I won't go into too much detail as I can't stand people who, accidentally or not, summarise a film to somebody who hasn't seen it. I feel, personally, this film is about imagery, though some might say it's about metaphor. Maybe in the book you're supposed to read in-between the lines, (which I haven't read, BTW) but I feel the film is simpler than that, and just wants to show you the fantasy in reality. The entire film is a work of beauty. Even the simplest of things is captured in a way to stun the audience. Be it a night sea lit up by thousands of jellyfish, or a simple, yet frightening storm throwing pi and Richard Parker - the Bengal tiger - from bow to stern was cinematic-ally, a truly breath-taking experience.I think this film is a breathe of fresh air in cinema as of late, you can leave feeling that you've seen something relatively different for a change. Not just a remake/reboot of something milked to the teeth (though I don't have a problem with those kinds of film, it's just nice seeing something new).I saw this film a few days after seeing the hobbit, and can honestly say I've thought about this film more in the days after. I'll leave that to you to ponder what that means regarding the impact of the 2 films.

reviews.review_title: Spectacular for Viewing, Inferior to Reading
reviews.content:
I hadn't wanted to see this film because I hadn't thought that the book could translate to film. In complexity it didn't exactly, but it was so visually beautiful that I was totally enchanted. My son's whispered questions ("Why is he crying?") when Pi killed a fish made the experience more meaningful than I had anticipated, since my son knows but probably doesn't understand my vegetarianism, which feels like religion.Despite the incredible cinematography of the movie, the image of a still boat on water could have been accompanied by Yann Martel's brilliant narrative: ruminations on the sea, "The sea roared like a tiger. The sea whispered in your ear like a friend telling you secrets. The sea clinked like small change in a pocket..."), or fear "It's life's only true opponent.
Only fear can defeat life...One moment you are feeling calm, self-possessed, happy. Then fear, disguised in the garb of mild-mannered doubt, slips into your mind like a spy...", the sacrilege of Pi killing a fish: "I felt I was beating a rainbow to death." Only in words could an orangutan be compared to the Virgin Mary, could God be described this way: "...God's hat was always unraveling. God's pants were falling apart. God's cat was a constant danger. God's ark was a jail. God's wide acres were slowly killing me. God's ear didn't seem to be listening." Even the spectacle of watching an excellent movie can't replace the full-bodied experience of reading a great book.

Also there is a pointless hospital scene near the end where Pi comes up with another story which is more believable and therefore a little confusing since it was even hinted that it may be the true story. reviews.review_title: Enjoyed the film in spite of some controversies

However, I wondered whether it was necessary to have the film in 3D, as one felt that the film could have been equally well enjoyed even without that. Irrfan Khan is as usual at his best, as the older Pi. The special effects are also fantastic, with the island of carnivorous trees so believable! And so is the quality of editing and casting. No wonder that the film has received several Oscar nominations. But, the only major point which jars is the controversy back home in India regarding the opening lullaby, over 80% of which is a straight lift through translation into Tamil from a celebrated Malayalam lullaby, Omanathingalkkidavo, composed by Irayimman Thampi exactly 200 years back, in 1813, on the occasion of the birth of Swati Tirunal, declared king even before birth, and who later became one of the four leading composers in Carnatic music of the era. Barring this obvious bit of plagiarism, the rest of the movie was thoroughly enjoyable. I wouldn't mind watching it again, merely for the cinematic skills.

reviews.review_title: Finding One's Path, According to Life of Pi
reviews.content: The Life of Pi is perhaps the most meaningful movie ever made. It follows the quest of Pi, an Indian religious zealot who is unsure of which religion he is zealous about. His quest, as displayed in the movie's cover, appears to be his survival on a boat with a tiger, but is actually a quest to find truth. And ultimately, the story is our quest too.The first part of the movie depicts Pi's childhood search for religion. Dabbling in Hinduism, Christianity, and Islam, he receives a small degree of flak from his family, especially his father, who believes that reason — not religion — should be one's starting point. His mother taught him the ways of Hinduism, and somewhat disagreed with her husband, saying: "Science can teach us things out there, but not in the heart." The second part of the movie follows Pi's survival on the lifeboat. His family has to leave the country and take up residence in Canada. Since they are zookeepers, they bring their animals on the ship. Unfortunately, a storm rages against the ship, and Pi is thrown to the ocean, along with some people and animals. Only he, a zebra, rat, tiger, hyena, an orangutan make it to the desperate shelter of a lifeboat as he watches his past sink beneath him.From this part on, the filmmakers pull out all their cinematography stops. From leagues of jelly fish to scores of flying fish the heavily incorporated CGI footage appears realistic. On the boat he learns how to survive on the ocean and cope with the tiger, the only surviving animal (for obvious reasons). He retains his commitment to never take a life for as long as possible, and is cautious, but not malicious, towards Richard Parker, the tiger. He learns survival coping skills, becomes resourceful, and lets his instinct rule as danger resides above (with the teeth of animals) and below (with teeth of sharks). The tiger's presence was good for Pi, as he reflected back on his life, "Attending to the tiger's needs gives my life purpose."Yes, Pi did eventually live, although he had given God everything, and felt he and the tiger were about to die. In the crux of a storm, he cried: "God, thank you for giving me my life." By good fortune he found an island disconnected from humanity, with plenty of food, animals, and water, but he concluded that it was not enough to truly sustain him. He traveled on until he reached the Mexican shore, survived, and went on to have a wife, cat, and some kids.Nice story.Yet, when he was picked up, nobody believed him. The amazing twist of this story is that all of this may not have happened. At the tail end of the movie, two Japanese men ask Pi to give them "a believable story" for their company. And Pi, after showing us the entire movie with the tiger, goes on to explain another — more "rational" story. But why, after all the beauty we've seen? Most people have given this movie high reviews, raving about the mesmerizing scenes, the CGI, the tension between Pi and the tiger, great acting, and sheer imagination in the film. While the movie contains all of these, I might suggest that the core of the movie is about none of them.This movie is like a bag full of gems. One could easily unpack the thousand symbolic wonders of this film. But the most unusual part of this movie is that it encourages the viewer to decide completely for themselves what to believe. We first see the story of the tiger, but the tiger could also represent Pi's evil instincts. As the movie unfolds, every event on the boat could be symbolic . . . or not. The island could be the bosom of a god. Or it could be symbolic of resting in humanity. Pi could have been interacting with the animals, or he could have been cannibalizing people (it goes to show that depth of content indeed can be found in PG rated movies).So, a dilemma occurs. Which do we choose? The first story was about miracles, phenomenal, sentimental, yet hard to believe. It is about what God was doing. The other is plain and believable: Pi simply sat on the hospital bed and told us. Yes, tears were streaming down his face, but it's easy to trivialize, and easier to forget. Nobody forgets the tiger.I believe that Pi told his story in such a way as to not be trivialized. Whether anyone believes it is up to them, but as the story unfolds, our hearts want to believe in the tiger. No matter which story we believe, the second story is given so much more depth and meaning when told in light of the first.If the first story wasn't told, it would be difficult to believe that God had a hand in the process. When someone shares their story, it's easy to trivialize their deliverance. Pi may have fantasized his story so we could see how important his deliverance is — physically and spiritually. He was able to realize in tribulation that God was making provision for him.When it comes down to it, The Life of Pi is open-ended, but not without leaving us in tension. It is our choice in how much we draw from this movie. Will we choose the logical, fact-driven view, rationalizing all the mystery, or should we embrace a providential, terrifying God who guides us as we trust him? Pi has given us all the options; now we must simply have faith.

reviews.review_title: It was a good movie but let's keep it 100.......
reviews.content: Do I really have to reiterate the plot? If you don't know the Life of Pi is about a young boy stranded at sea with a Bengal Tiger, then I want to know what rock you've been sleeping under and how long. But seriously, that's pretty much what the movie is about. The movie also chronicles the life a young boy named Pi from his early childhood up until and after the ordeal.Let me start off by stating the visuals are excellent. I saw this movie in 3D (as if there's any other way to see it) and I think the composers did a masterful job creating a dynamic of animals and humans with the same feelings and facial expressions. The movie utilized awesome 3D visual effects to put you smack dab in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.The plot is simple but intriguing. There is something about the idea of being stranded in the middle of the ocean that awes the public. Add in the fact that your stranded with a wild animal is even more fun. The film focuses on the struggle of human survival in addition to spiritual enlightenment.I know what you're thinking. "If the movie had all these good things, why did you rate it a 6?" That's a good question, so I'll give you my reasons. After about 40 minutes into the movie I began to wonder where all this was going. The movie seemed to drag on and on with little indication there was any meaning to it all. You go through about an hour and a half of fishing, sea storms and animal taming. It was like Cast Away on the Pacific Ocean. The offshore adventure was fun until about 45 minutes. After that, the film just seemed to drag on with one futile triumph after another.There were religious and faith-based references throughout the movie, and the narrator made it clear there would be some type of revelation at the conclusion; leaving you with an anticipation of an prophetic event or climax. However, the film never really delivered. As weird as it sounds, there was nothing much out of the ordinary that happened in this story from any other story about a boy stranded in the sea with a wild tiger. The fact that he was stranded at sea with a wild tiger was what was out of the ordinary. Get me? I came into the movie expecting to be taken on an epic journey that left me with some great revelation. Instead, it was like watching an extended HD documentary on the discovery channel concluding with a dubious spiritual message. Don't get me wrong, I liked the movie. I mean, I like watching the Discovery Channel. As I mentioned before, the movie had great visuals and an interesting plot. I just don't think it lived up to all the hype and had the phenomenal effect so many people claimed it to have. To each his own though.

reviews.review_title: Life of Pi is an adaption of the novel by the same name.
reviews.content: The movie tells the story of a 16-year old boy named Piscine Molitor "Pi" Patel, who survives a shipwreck in which his family dies, and is stranded in the Pacific Ocean on a lifeboat with a wounded zebra, an orangutan, a spotted hyena, and a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker. The story in itself is very straightforward, but was still captivating enough to keep me interested to actually finish the movie. Personally, I didn't find the movie in itself that interesting and could have been told through a short film. The story is very tame, but certainly had the potential to actually be interesting. With that said the cinematography and soundtrack is what carries this entire movie. Every single scene in this movie is visually breath taking and makes me think of James Cameron's Avatar. Just like Avatar it demonstrates what happens when you have an unoriginal manuscript but an overambitious director, skilled cinematographer, and truck loads of CGI. If the movie had had more substance to it and wasn't just a display of modern technology it might have actually won the Academy Award for best motion picture.

reviews.review_title: A few holes in a beautiful fabric

reviews.review_title: A very touching , inspiring , and unique movie .
reviews.content: Which story is the true one ? the one that has the animals or the one that has the cook, the sailor and Pi's mother ? that's the question I asked myself after finishing the movie .Actually I thought at the beginning that the tiger story was the true one , but I rejected that opinion later .. as if it was that simple the movie would be so shallow , and I didn't feel that during watching it , also the company representative said that bananas don't float , etc.So , what other explanations do we have ? The only explanation I could come up with is that the story - the one that has the tiger in it - was symbolic .. the novelist himself explained that by matching the characters .. the hyena is the cook , the zebra is the sailor , the orangutan is Pi's mother , and of course the tiger is Pi .I thought it was very brilliant to show that humans could be sometimes animalistic in their actions if they were put in circumstances that stimulates their instincts , such as hunger , thirst , feeling unsafe , etc.And as we've seen, maternal instinct overcomes other instincts , and the only character that faced its animalistic symbol was Pi ..So , I think that the whole story was to show us the facing between 2 different pictures of man .. evil and good .Also I've been impressed by directing , acting .. Suraj made me cry over .. a tiger !A very touching , inspiring , and unique movie .But I've one question : how should this story make me believe in god ?! (though I do believe in him) .. also I didn't get the point of him being following 3 religions , was it to show us how tolerance should be ? worshiping different gods beside the one I believe in ? that was very uncalled for .

reviews.review_title: 2 Stories About This Film of 2 Stories
reviews.content: One story is about how wonderful, enchanting, and full of religious experience is this film.The other story is about how a vapid film with a plot you begin to doubt at nearly the outset closes with the feeling of having gone nowhere. Is this film a screenplay emulation of Samuel Beckett?It reminds me of "Waiting for Godot" in which 2 characters go on and on with each other until the play ends, or "Molloy" where Beckett writes, "It is midnight. The rain is beating on the windows. It was not midnight. It was not raining.".A vastly overrated film.

reviews.review_title: The Voyage of Two: Review of "Life of Pi"
reviews.content:
The Voyage of Two: Review of "Life of Pi"
The stunning movie "Life of Pi" combines endearment yet a feeling of hopelessness in a miraculous adventure. Most of the time Hollywood is a hit or miss, but Ang Lee in 2012 directed a special gem for sure. From the wonderful nature of India to the cold waters of the Pacific, the scenery never fails to be awe-inspiring. Floating off into a remarkable journey, the admirable Irrfan Khan has put out an incomparable performance that is one for the history books as it won multiple Oscars in 2013. By combining elements such as hopelessness and faith the movie "Life of Pi" has become an absolute masterpiece.The movie also touches on topics such as devotion and passion which ripples through its cinematography and thrilling narrative. Pi is first seen as a young boy who is the son of a zoo owner. The zoo was magnificent as it housed creatures from zebras, orangutans, all the way to Richard Parker who was a Bengal tiger. Because of this zoo it brought forth the attachment that he had developed with the animals he would tend. Pi was also very passionate about religion as he did not only practice one but three. The three were Hinduism, Christianity, and Islam as you will learn about these while you follow him through his road to adulthood. These both influence and create miraculous feelings of emotion such as joy or excitement while you gaze upon the wonderful surroundings of the film.Something that you or a loved one never wants to feel is the sense of hopelessness or discouragement. You may be familiar with these as they come up quite often in today's world. For example, If you did not understand the topics in a class that you were enrolled in you may sense a demoralizing feeling. This does not mean that you cannot overcome these obstacles as you may find some help down the road from loved ones. Family is a major part in our lives and sometimes all we have, losing this can cause some to spiral down the wrong path. Pi was once an untroubled kid looking forward to a bright future in India. That all changed when his father decided it would be best for the family financially to move to Canada. With the decision seemingly set the family gathered their belongings and boarded a cargo ship to transfer them across the Pacific Ocean. In the mists of night an outrageous storm breaks swaying the ship back and forth. Happening so quickly Pi had managed to reach the lifeboat but not without shouting and desperately trying to look for his family onboard. An unfortunate incident lunges the small raft into the murky waters of the Pacific and with that the ship and his family are never seen again. This would forever change the course of Pi's life and his views of the world.From the beautiful night sky to the gorgeous environment underwater, "Life of Pi" truly transcends cinematography and takes it to the next level. As Pi drifts off into the neverending, you are met with astonishing sights such as whales feeding on shrimp and even flying fish that seem to be migrating. Not to mention his stunning partner in crime Richard Parker, has done nothing but impress with his handsome and yet daunting characteristics. These two were not so friendly when they had first met but due to the circumstances they seemed to come to a mutual understanding. With that being realized Pi had managed to string together a routine for Richard Parker to cover his liveliness. Eventually the duo seem to catch a break as an Island appears in the distance which can provide shelter in the meantime. In a way you get "Cast Away" vibes as the two traverse the newly acquainted land. Being in the water for so long can make any piece of land feel like heaven for some. Yet the eerie feeling and close observation of Pi comes to the conclusion that the Island is actually a death trap and he must move on. The attractive island's time comes to an end as the magnificent creatures in the ocean await for Pi's return. Back in what seems like Hell on Earth, the story still gives off a stagger surprise to those who continued to believe. The journey that seems to be going on forever does indeed resume as Pi and Richard Parker strike land that turns out to be Mexico. Upon his return to humanity Pi had received an unexpected response to his experience that he had just overcome. This really did not bother Pi at all, unfortunately the thing that did was the unceremonial goodbye from Richard Parker. Fortunately a wife and child would accommodate Pi later on in life giving him gratification. Through the wisdom of religion and determination to live, Pi and Richard Parker were able to get the better of the treacherous sea.
Faith in "Life of Pi" crosses the boundary of film and real life lessons to take on. If you have enjoyed other movies such as, "Open Waters" or "Abandoned" then I see no reason for you to not appreciate this wonder of a film. Many Hollywood movies deam no true real life value and are often created for the sole purpose of profit. What makes "Life of Pi" different is the fact you realize how grateful you are and what truly makes living a beauty. With all of the astounding scenery and spoken wisdom it legitimately is a filmmaking gem which the world should be thrilled to be able to gaze upon.Works Cited PageLife of Pi. Directed by Ang Lee, Performances by Irrfan Khan, Rafe Spall, Twentieth Century Fox, 2012.

ANURADHA SAHA
Date 09/06/2021
MOVIE NAME- LIFE OF PI
RELEASE DATE- 23 NOVEMBER,2012 .DIRECTOR- Ang Lee .CAST- Irrfan khan, Suraj sharma,Tabu .Story: Based on Man Booker-prize winning novel 'Life of Pi' by Canadian author Yann Martel, this film tells the incredible survival story of Pi, a teen stranded on a lifeboat for what seems like forever, with a tiger for company at sea in the Pacific Ocean.Review: Starting out with the older Pi (Irrfan Khan) recounting his unbelievable life story to an author (Rafe Spall), we travel down memory lane and are briefly introduced to Pi's childhood in picturesque Puducherry (Pondicherry), his family-owned zoo and his faith in God and religion.It is spoiling nothing to disclose that Pi Patel, the younger son of an Indian zoo owner, survives a terrible shipwreck during a storm in the Pacific Ocean. That much you know from the very first scenes of "Life of Pi," Ang Lee's 3-D film adaptation of the wildly popular, arguably readable novel by Yann Martel. A middle-aged Pi (the reliably engaging Irrfan Khan) tells the tale of his earlier life to a wide-eyed Canadian novelist (Rafe Spall), so we know that he made it through whatever ordeal we are about to witness.LOP's soothing background score and gorgeous imagery transports you to a world of beauty, where the sky looks as sublime as the sea and the stars shine as brightly as the ripple of a stone thrown in the water.Whether a viewer's good will can survive until the shipwreck is another matter. The older Pi introduces us to his younger self (played as a boy by Ayush Tandon and as a teenager by Suraj Sharma), whose life is so besotted by wonder that those in the audience .The movie's two central characters both obtained their names by comic accident. The deeply serious Piscine (played by Gautam Belur at five, Ayush Tandon at 12 and Suraj Sharma at 16)was named after an uncle's favourite swimming pool, the Piscine Molitor in Paris, but changed his name to the Greek letter and numinous number Pi after fellow schoolboys made jokes about pissing. He later became fascinated by a Bengal tiger in the zoo caught by the English hunter Richard Parker who called him Thirsty. On delivery to the zoo their names were accidently reversed and the tiger became Richard Parker. Was this fate or chance?Ang Lee interweaves adventure and spirituality brilliantly. And if you still don't know what meditation feels like, Watch Life of Pi, it is therapeutic and profound.#MARACTIVITY

reviews.review_title: Life is to put it down constantly, but it's sad that I haven't been able to say goodbye to them properly
reviews.content: Everyone yearns for beautiful things in his heart, but he is always unable to change the cruelty of reality. Only by adjusting his attitude can he find a way out for life. The school regards the glimmer of dawn that penetrates the dark clouds as a miracle, and we have not found the courage to move forward because of the vision of light. Life is a process of letting go, and one day we can face the regrets in life with ease. "Life is to put it down constantly, but it's sad that I haven't been able to say goodbye to them properly." Imax scores a lot. This is not the best film for 3D effects, but dazzling visual effects, not dazzling visual effects, are integrated with the film. The beautiful scene, like a dream and philosophy, is a perfect dialogue between faith and reason. It is not so important which is true or false.

After escaping from the zoo, Pi gets stranded on a boat with a lion named John Snow and proceeds to survive on the sea and has hallucinations about an island that is alive, whales, his girlfriend (played by Michael Cera) etc. In his time he develops a unique surfing style with his lion. The minimal use of CGI was impressive, the fact that they filmed the whole movie in the Atlantic ocean is amazing, kudos to the director and producer. The tiger wrangling scene particularly in such a small space was an impressive feat by today's film standards in industry inundated with VFX. The experience was an immersive experience made one get as lost as Pi. Cast was believable, enjoyable movie, 3/10.

reviews.review_title: Movie that engages you from beginning to end
reviews.content: This movie shows the journey of a young Indian boy who moved with his family and all the animals from their zoo to Canada on a large Japanese ship. The ship sinks during a big storm. He survives on a rescue vessel along with a zebra, hyena, orangutan and a Bengal tiger, named Richard Parker. Eventually he is left only with the tiger. The movie mainly focuses on the way he builds a relation ship with the tiger along with the dangers of trying to do that. The story is told as he is talking to an American friend who will write a book about his adventure. You really get into the skin of his boy, like you feel the frustration of being on a vessel for months with a tiger and surviving on crackers and no food for the tiger, which forces the boy to be creative and catch fish to keep the tiger alive and away from him. Eventually he is able to train the tiger and enables him to be around the tiger without being eaten. The end of the movie is awesome when the story becomes a metaphor for the loss of his family. The movie has some very touching moments where you can just imagine being in the precarious position the boy is in. I didn't see it in 3D but still found the effects amazing. It's not really a movie for smaller children < 12, because of the deepness of certain parts of the movie. Definitely a movie I could see again sometimes.

I recently went to see a film that I had waited to see for a long time and was desperately disappointed. That film was The Hobbit. The 3D effects and 48 FPS rate were dreadful, and deflected from the film. The life of Pi on the other hand was a triumph. As an avid film goer, I have found 3D to be one of the biggest letdowns of my age. With the exception of Avatar I have found it to be a big distractor when watching a film. The Life of Pi takes you back to the initial success of Avatar. Never gimmicky, only highlighting the sheer beauty of the film. The depth of background was always there. The film itself was what I consider Cinema to be all about, that feeling when you walk out, knowing you had witnessed something magical. Try to go to see this film, you will not be disappointed if, like me,you believe in that magic.

My very first movie review ever! I have Dysthymia. Many people don't know what that is, so I will spell it out for you. I am perpetually in a state of chronic mild depression, where only my severe apathy prevents me from deciding to just commit suicide.I go about life feeling almost nothing. But every now and then I am moved. They are just moments, even sparks, of emotion. Such as when a girl says she loves me, or when one of my pets dies, or when something absolutely beautiful catches my eye and I seem to be the only one around noticing it, as if the that event was just for me. Otherwise I feel nothing. I very rarely laugh, or am angry, or happy, sad, lonely, excited, etc. This movie almost kept me in a state of emotion for 1 whole hour! And to top that I actually shed tears!I have always loved cats. In fact watching one of the big cats get shot for sport is one of the few things that make me angry. So I guess there is no surprise when I say this is most beautiful love story I have ever had the privilege of watching.And I would like to thank everyone involved, from the producer to the millions of viewers that watched and rated this high so it would catch my attention, for giving me that 1 hour. It is something I will never forget. Which is unfortunate, because I would give up a years worth of income to experience that one more time, as if I was watching it again for the first time.

The movie is engrossing, in some places admirable. I acknowledge his metaphors and his features that make people think and wonder, and I like them even if they are not exaggerated. But the visuals have been enlarged a little, I think. There are some particularly beautiful prominent scenes as well, Ang Lee is a director who already has a "visual style" of his own. But I do not think it is so praiseworthy in every place. The movie makes the audience feel something. Those who read his book before will of course establish a different connection and evaluate it differently. I would say think about the movie after watching it, or even read a couple of analyzes.

reviews.review_title: An awkward version of Robinson Crusoe
reviews.content: Very disappointed with the movie, it's truly an awkward version of Robinson Crusoe, the only highlight is the picture is very sharp and beautiful.From the start, you feel like the director was trying to delivery some message along the story line, as the family met a storm at the sea, and PI became the only human being that survived in the sunk of the Japanese ship, along with a few animals from his father's zoo, you think that might be the start of the "moment of truth", but even to the end, the message is still not clear nor strong, making the viewers feeling lost.The high-tide is PI's experience at the sea, there're a lot of unreasonable scenes, like when a lot of fish flying over the boat and hit him, he seems pretty much intact, and after long struggle at the sea, he still looks fat and white.

I was going to see this movie without any expectations. And so I did. The collaboration between the tiger and the kid where extraordinary good. And how everything fits together (the water, animals and setting) is just great to see. As for a visual statement of the movie I'd say that this movie is absolutely great, they had some great animators at their studio to make this happen, it just all looks so great! You are getting sucked into the movie, it's so realistic as for the colours and audio. At the end there is an interesting line which I not going to say because of spoilers, but the setting just fits. There is one thing I found annoying about this movie: The stupidity of the kid. He makes one foolish act after each other, but does manage to make a fishing rod and some other stuff where you do have to have some brains to think that it out. It kind of does not really fit in, on the one hand he seems smart, but on the other hand he is really stupid. Seems like a contradiction, but I think you will just have to accept that. The story is amazing and you can just watch the movie without any problems. It's fun to watch.

What is the best thing about a foggy Sunday morning in L.A.? Watching "Life of Pi" on BluRay. After seeing the film in 3D last year, I personally felt as a film it deserved "Best Picture" from the Motion Picture Academy. Ang Lee won his second Oscar for "Achievement in Directing" for "Pi" but this Oscar nominated film lost to "Argo" (another great film). Ang also won for Best Director on "Brokeback Mountain" which lost it's best picture nom to "Crash". That year I attended the Oscars and half the audience got up and applauded for "Crash" while the other half (myself included) sat in protest that "Brokeback" lost. The feeling that night was the overriding evidence that homophobia was alive and well in Hollywood. But I digress. "Life of Pi" is an amazing film. The special effects with the animals is incredible (I could not tell what was real and what wasn't), and performances were amazing, especially by young Suraj Sharma as PI; he at least deserved an Oscar nomination. But again I digress. Rarely do literary books translate to the visual craft of storytelling in film but this is that wonderful exception to the rule. It's officially on my list and part of the my DVD library. Possibly Ang's best film yet.

Not overly impressed or interested in the story itself, and it became tedious after a short while. The visual effects and CG animals were done wonderfully. I conked out after about 20 minutes. I wasn't thrilled with the tiger attacking and chomping on the other surviving creatures. Being on a rocking boat got on my nerves, because I have poor vision, and it took great effort to focus in on the action on-screen. The zebra didn't deserve to be 'hunted' as it was, and savaged so, even though it's done out of sight. The shipwreck itself was done well, though I'd have had a hair more human panic involved. People aren't rational in a shipwreck. They tend to panic and make things worse, plus, face it. men will toss any woman out of his way if it means his survival. Whoever yells 'women and children first' better have a machine gun trained on the men.

Beautifully made movie about the complex relationship between Good and Evil, Man and God. The only negative is that the movie is so visually stunning that it may lead the viewer to appreciate it only on the physical concrete plane.The real point to the movie is to show us that the tiger is not in the boat trying to kill the boy, rather that there is a metaphorical tiger living in each of us, and it is through the mythology of religions that each of us may discover for ourselves how we deal with our own tiger.In this way, I think that the medium of film cannot match the impact of the written text for a film of such metaphoric import. It is through the imagery created in each individual's mind through the living life experiences of each person reading the passages of the book that give it deeper personal meaning and sense to the metaphor. This movie, as every movie, must impart the visions and experiences of essentially one person, the director. But it is such a beautiful vision after all.

reviews.review_title: gives you enough space to investigate and question so as to understand
reviews.content: Thought I'd write this down while it's still fresh in my mind.What struck me during the movie was how relevant it was to my own life, especially with regards to my relationship with my husband, Beat seen through the eyes of everything I have learnt through Buddhism.We come face to face with our deepest fears when we are forced to live with a being as dangerous as the tiger with the soul in its eyes being only a reflection of our emotions. Or is it? The tiger is merely a manifestation or projection of what is within ourselves. This same tiger could symbolize a person, situation or thing.The tiger is our teacher however and we should thank it for teaching us greater understanding and compassion once we can open up and accept it for what it truly is and its nature hence also accept that part inherent in ourselves which we fear and fight. The tiger keeps us alert, tending to its needs gives us purpose and ultimately keeps us alive within a seemingly helpless situation.We are all teachers in even just what we do silently and the boy is as much a teacher to the tiger as the tiger is to him. Actions transcends language as evident in the relationship between man and animal. Being forced to live together on a lifeboat and a makeshift floating platform at sea taught them both the greatest virtue of patience. The roles of the predator/prey or hunter/hunted becomes reversed at some point in the story. Compassion prevailed insteadWe can also learn to appreciate the impermanence and transience of life in that this too will pass which is a proverb indicating that all material conditions, positive or negative, are temporary in the greater scheme of things.Perhaps when we finally reach shore to safety, the tiger would walk right out of our lives and leave us unceremoniously once and for all without even 'looking back' hence help us acknowledge the truth of what's happened, that a final separation from that person has occurred. And in that acceptance we come to peace. The departure of the tiger could also just signify the change of quality within a relationship.In the same way, life doesn't go according to plan anyways and we could lose our loved ones suddenly in an unexpected turn of events in a shipwreck. We will all grow old and die someday. Our whole lives is a grand orchestration of letting go.But we are not the same boy as we were when we unwittingly started out on the greatest journey of our lives that would change our lives forever.Does God exist? Who knows for sure? Perhaps our individual journey is to discover the mind; with the realization of the ultimate reality or enlightenment being the closest quality of experience in proximity hence intimacy to a God we could experience as stated in the Hindu scriptures.Now I can honestly say that I can appreciate all the above-mentioned in the movie; Life of Pi.

First of all, I must say I believe in God and I came across the book when I was in India on a spiritual journey. I watched the film afterward, after coming home, to see if the movie had do any justice to the spiritual theme. It did not, I think...I must admit that the visuals are spectacular as many reviewers have already pointed out, and I also found the acting all right, but I truly believe this story lacks the core, or rather it MISSES the point it has claimed it wanted to convey!So I give only 3/10 because come on, spirit is missing from this story! How can they claim anyone will believe in God after seeing this?! Mentioning His name some times in the film won't cause any miracles! This whole conclusion of story is only about a mental trick to cope with a traumatic incident! It may be symbolic and the end may be heart-wrenching (in a bad, sad way, I think), but it is just a pseudo-spiritual, inconsistent, dark story which confuses but never uplifts!I must admit, in the beginning the story really dealt with the religious theme more, but as soon as Pi got shipwrecked, it all was like switching to a completely another story... Oh, and it felt even too slow and uneventful... Both during the book and the film. And I still don't really understand what they wanted to symbolize by that strange island. It was so out-of-place.I think it is unfair to advertise this as spiritual, uplifting, finding-God-by-watching-it... It's a mistaken, over-rated hype. I'm glad if it added anything valuable to anyone who has watched it, but all I felt was that the writer wasn't really sure what he wanted to write about...
