"Life of Pi" 10 Scale Rating: 7.0 (Good) ...

The Good: Visually stunning and impressive considering that the cast mostly consists of one boy and a CGI tiger. For me though, the better parts of the film occur before he becomes stranded. The scenes of him growing up and his relationship with his family was very well done.

The Bad: I didn't really enjoy the ending very much. The author of the novel (who did like the film) has stated that he intended it to be more ambiguous. I think that would have made a far better ending.

Life of Pi proves that not all epics consist of tons of characters and extras. Just a young Indian boy with his CGI friend. Whether this film is real or not, the question must never be answered. Its all real. Life of Pi asks us to take a journey with a young boy Pi and a Bengal tiger Richard Parker across the harsh ocean that they endure as this epic. Creating this grand adventure so cinematically bold, one feels as though they are venturing on the small boat with Pi and Richard. I watched this film in 2D and even that was immerse and interactive, so the 3D must have been reality. Based on Yann Martel's novel Lee and screenwriter David Magee have managed to stay true to the source without being constrained by it, as so often happens in adaptations. Lee has done what no other director has ever been seen done and that is enhancing the novel's power, employing 3D and CGI technology with such originality that there are moments when the ocean seems to float around you. And when a certain tiger roars, you may well jump. I know I did. 

As magnetic as Ang Lee's boundary-breaking visuals are, it wouldn't be enough to carry the film if it were not anchored by such an electrifying tale. The core is the 227 days Pi spends in the lifeboat with the spiritual Tiger and relationship between the two truly is magnificent. Both tear filling and important. Suraj Sharma is very faithful to his character and for his debut film his acting is more than sufficient. Lets just hope he doesn't end up like Dev Patel. This film exceeds all my expectations. Its flawless. Nothing more and nothing less. And lets face it should have won best picture. Fear becomes Pi's first ally when a storm rips at the ship. The will to survive will kick in later. He's thrown into one of the lifeboats and in the chaos that follows, some of the zoo's belongings join him - a frantic zebra, a fussy orangutan, a frenzied hyena and Richard Parker, who boards despite Pi's best efforts to keep him at away. 

You might think spending the bulk of the film in a lifeboat would soon lose its intrigue. But when there are wild animals, unpredictable seas and diminishing rations there is no time for things to get boring. Life of Pi is a rare kind of film and we won't be seeing anything like or up to its level in the neat future. Ang has directed a film that will surly stay with us forever more and what more is there to say. Well done Ang Lee. Verdict: With the stunning visuals, the miraculous storyline and Ang Lee's direction, Life of Pi is defiantly the best in its category. Life of Pi is Ang Lee's best film to date. And don't forget your tissues!

Totally different to what I was expecting, although to be honest I'm not exactly sure what I was anticipating - Something mightily complex and scientific I reckon, what with 'Pi' being the centre of attention. It was actually like a mini Noah's Ark tale though which largely took place in the one setting in the middle of the Ocean. Having lost his family in a horrid storm whilst travelling aboard a cargo ship full of his parents zoo animals, the castaway surfaces adrift from the wreck with only four animals for company, one of which being the Bengal tiger at the top of the food chain. Whilst battling one another, as well as their own thirst and hunger, we witness how the struggle unfolds, and just how unbelievable the events turn out to be. Will anyone believe what happened out there, or are we just witnessing a fantasy version that masks the true events? Either way, it captures the imagination through a mixture of stunning animation, religious beliefs and innovative cinematography. Its just about the right length as any longer and the enticement of the watery setting may have become little tenuous, regardless of how pretty it may look in 3D. It's certainly not one to watch repeatedly, but a unique story that all the family should enjoy at least once in their lifetime.

Life of Pi is a story about a boy who tests his faith and beliefs while being stranded in the middle of the ocean after their ship got sunk by a storm. It's ought to be an inspiring tale to make one believe in God. In the end, there's only few questions to ask, but what made this spectacular is the amazing use of special effects and the direction. You do not always get a film as gorgeous and as highly enjoyable as this one. It's one of the best kinds of experiences you'll get in cinemas. It has real tension, humor, and emotional depth, but the real landmark here is the visuals that are undeniably spellbinding.

The beginning is quite intriguing as it talks about faith and its morality, but the conundrum disappointingly ends up being less subtle in execution. Despite of that, we still get to see something extraordinary. One is a genuine fortitude in every suspenseful and emotional moment which practically compels the whole picture. The other is obviously the visuals. Ang Lee interestingly turned the survival into a whimsical and surreal exterior that made this look so remarkable like when the water perfectly reflects the stars in the sky or the lightning struck at the entire ocean during a harsh storm. The CGI-ed animals are amazing how they move and act like real animals. The enjoyable bits is when Pi interacts with those band of misfits. The film is in 3D and yep, there are plenty of things jumped off the screen(noticeably changes ratio aspect in one sequence), but it also shows some interesting use of it.

There's only few things to say about this since I haven't read the book(rule breaker here), but I'll say it has the same root of Cloud Atlas. "Life of Pi" opens numerous avenues for discussion and debate - but I'll try to keep this short (as all the other "reviews" I write on here). I must, first, admit that I've not read the book prior to seeing the movie. In fact, I knew very little of the story going into the movie. I think going into the movie with such a blank slate (or tabula rasa) is the best way to experience "Life of Pi". 
"Life of Pi" tells the incredible struggle of a teenaged boy who defies the impossible and survives 227 days in the middle of the Pacific in a lifeboat with the companionship of a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker. The teenaged boy is named Pi - after taking much abuse from his classmates growing up because of his real name, Piscine (or Pissing), he shortens his name to Pi and adopts the infinite number as his moniker. Quite fitting. 
Pi, in essence, offers two stories to the viewers/listeners. One story is powerful, imaginative, visceral - and if you accept it, you accept God(?). The other story is more probable and realistic - but does that mean if you believe it, then you don't believe in God? That's left to the viewer to decide. 
No matter what you believe, you can't deny the extraordinary beauty that director Ang Lee and co. provide us. Some of the best moments are when Lee combines the water of the ocean, our hero and his tiger companion, and the stars above as one. For the time Pi spends lost at sea, he and the tiger are the only beings left in the world - maybe even the entire universe. 
Ang Lee deservedly won the Oscar for Best Director. This is one of those rare movies that stays with you long after you've left the theater (or, in my case, turned off the Bluray player).

Powerful adaptation of the book with the same name. Pi is a teenage Indian boy living in the zoo of Pondicherry (India). Due to lack of business his family decide to emigrate to Canada with the animals but the ship they are travelling in sinks during a mighty storm. By a twist of fate Pi manages to escape from the ship in a lifeboat in the company of an injured zebra, a hyena, an orang-utan and a tiger called Richard Parker. After the hyena kills the zebra and the orang-utan, Richard Parker ends up eating them all up and Pi is forced to build a raft in order to survive. The movie follows Pi's attempts to tame the tiger and his adventures as a castaway. Eventually Richard Parker becomes the very reason not to fall into desperation and to carry on living. 
It is a beautifully filmed movie, with powerful images of the sea, the sky, the stars... I was a little disappointed to find out that the tiger was computer generated, but to be honest, it is so perfectly done that you cannot spot the difference.
A lot of people have wanted to see something else in this story, a reflection of human nature (where each animal represents a feature of human personality) or an insight into religion (the tiger meaning the soul). But I also believe that there is a real possibility of this just being the narrative of a remarkable survivor. It is up to each viewer; the film acts a mirror of our own experiences.

Brief history review number three: Life of Pi. This was, honestly, one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. Comparisons to Avatar are fair only because they are both visually stunning. But where Avatar is unashamedly anti-capitalist, anti-American, and anti-military, with its pro-aboriginal message, Pi takes thought provoking and existentialiat views at theism and rationalism, at what motivates us and what drives us, what gives us reason to live. And while I don't think it possible to be a Hindu Catholic Muslim that teaches Judaism, Life of Pi presented this notion without offense, without slander. I found it intense without being cheesy,moving without being sappy, emotional without being a tear-jerker; a visual marvel that reminded me more of What Dreams May Come than it did of Avatar. I purchased the movie expecting to be impressed, and I got more than I bargained for. I only wish I had seen it in 3D. It is one of the better films that I've seen in my young life. Ang Lee is truly a genius (Hulk notwithstanding). I can't think of a single flaw in this movie. It's perfect. A plus.

It is an extraordinarily rare feat when a film can ask so very much of its audience, and in end -- give it all back plus extra. The Life of Pi accomplishes that and needs very little else.

The film and its director, Ang Lee, won numerous awards, but it is baffling to think about how many it didn't win. There is with little doubt that Life of Pi delivers one of the best films of 2012 and destroys all signs of existence from it's competition off the stage.

Just watching trailers, it can bee seen how just visually stunning the film is. Who knew that being stranded on a small boat in the middle of the ocean could be so glamorous and riveting. 

And with that said, it must be noted that it wasn't the visuals that carried this film. Beyond the visuals is a story so deep and so entwined into the fabrics of our imaginations that we can't help but sit in awe. The emotional give and take from the film is an experience in and of itself.

Ang Lee challenges your very thought processes and engages your mind from start to finish. The audience feels as if they are experiencing the world and learning new lessons right along with Pi.

Writers David Magee and Yann Martel took source material that broke down the barriers of our imaginations and transcribed it into a script that would only enhance the intricate complexities contained within.

Suraj Sharma took that script to another level. Spending most of the film alone in the middle of the ocean and in the company of a tiger, Sharma is able to translate, enforce, and relegate sheer amounts of power and will through the screen unto the audience. If he were to fall flat, so would the message he was expected to deliver. 

The story within the story, Piception if you will, keeps you fully engaged and needing more.

On one hand, you have a great film worthy of the many awards it won. On the other, you have art. A masterpiece that goes beyond the everyday bounds of film making and one in which that takes you on a spectacular journey through the deepest crevices of your mind, body, and soul.

Which is it that YOU believe?

Life of Pi is a colourful, fantastic and philosophical drama that overwhelms the senses with colours, calm and raging storms.  Pi is a young boy who lives with his parents and brother in a zoo.  The zoo is to be closed and so his family take the animals on a freighter as they leave India for Canada.  

A storm occurs, the ship sinks and only Pi, a zebra, a tiger, and a hyena survive by entering a lifeboat.  
Later an orangutan comes aboard the lifeboat.

The hyena attacks and kills the zebra then the orangutan and then the tiger kills the hyena.  Pi and the tiger come to a standoff during their fight to survive.  They land on a mysterious island with meerkats on it but abandon it to stay alive.  They finally reach Mexico where the tiger vanishes and Pi is found by people and eventually makes it to Canada.  We see Pi in later years narrating the story to an author and it is in returning to that context that the film is saved from completely faltering on a weak premise of a disturbing lie being accepted by accident investigators who want to know why the ship sank when Pi doesn't even know.

The story falters when Pi is interviewed about the accident.  He tells them his story but as they don't
believe much of it, he then fashions a false story in which the details are tragic and absurd and even in the service of the storyline and plot rings false and that pulled me out of sympathy with the movie (I stopping the film to write this review).  8/10
